news.title: The Most Surprising Moments from Melania Trump's Documentary: Barron's Safety Concerns, Kamala's Sigh and a Michael Jackson Singalong
news.text:
First lady Melania Trump's new film opened on Friday, Jan. 30, marking a rare global theatrical release for a documentary.

 Melania was reportedly purchased by Amazon MGM Studios for a stunning $40 million ‚Äî 70% of which may have gone directly into the first lady's pocket, The Wall Street Journal claims ‚Äî and had a $35 million marketing budget that included putting Melania's face on the Las Vegas Sphere.

 The first lady hosted an exclusive first viewing at the White House on Saturday, Jan. 24, in the midst of unrest in Minneapolis over the fatal shooting of American citizen Alex Pretti, calling the screening a "historic moment."

 The official Melania premiere, which took over the Kennedy Center on Thursday, Jan. 29, was limited to invited guests of the first family, with a politics-heavy black carpet beforehand that saw prominent Republican lawmakers and Cabinet members answering questions about foreign policy, immigration and budget negotiations on Capitol Hill.

 The documentary, which Melania described at her premiere as "beautiful," "emotional," "fashionable," and "cinematic," took an untraditional format, forgoing talking head interviews and instead leaning heavily into voiceovers by the first lady.

 Directed by controversial Hollywood filmmaker Brett Ratner, the film offers viewers a selective glimpse at the weeks leading up to the Jan. 20, 2025, inauguration, as Melania does fittings for her inaugural outfits, plots her East Wing agenda with other political spouses and attends the numerous events surrounding her husband's second swearing-in ceremony.

 Here are the most notable moments from Melania.

 The music choices, including a lot of Michael Jackson 

 Melania suggested that she picked the music carefully while teasing her documentary at the New York Stock Exchange before its premiere, saying, "Visual storytelling and beautiful music create memories for a lifetime. What do you remember when you hear Rolling Stones? Michael Jackson? Films bring families and friends together, sitting side by side, sharing a collective moment."

 Her musical references lacked context at the time, but are now understood to play a significant role in setting the tone of her documentary right at the beginning, with "Gimme Shelter" by the Rolling Stones ‚Äî a band who previously delivered a cease-and-desist to President Donald Trump ‚Äî kicking off the opening scene, followed quickly by Michael Jackson's "Billie Jean" as she travels from Mar-a-Lago to Manhattan to begin inauguration prep.

 Jackson, as the movie reveals, is her favorite musical artist, and "Billie Jean" her favorite song by him. Partway through the film, she recalls meeting Jackson with her husband once, adding, "He was very sweet. Very nice." Then "Billie Jean" plays again, and she quietly sings along to it in the car.

 Several other hits get their moment in the spotlight during the film, including Aretha Franklin's "Amazing Grace," Boney M.'s "Sunny," The Crystals' "Then He Kissed Me," and Tears for Fears' "Everybody Wants to Rule the World," the last of which plays when she and Donald make their final voyage to Washington before the inauguration.

 Fine-tuning the inauguration hat 

 The film documents Melania's back and forth with designers about her various outfits for inauguration weekend, showing her providing mostly positive feedback at fittings. When she sees her black-and-white inaugural ball outfit, for example, she says, "Very my colors, black and white. Very me."

 It also shows the behind-the-scenes conversations surrounding her unforgettable inauguration hat. The wide-brimmed accessory, which she wore for the first half of Inauguration Day, immediately turned into an internet meme when she was pictured at formal events throughout the morning with her face almost entirely covered, and her husband was caught struggling to kiss her on the cheek before taking the oath of office.

 The documentary reveals that the hat had potential to be even bigger. When her designer pulled it out at a fitting to seek her approval, she looked at it and said, "What do you think if we do not so wide?"

 Insights about Barron 

 Little is revealed about Barron Trump, the only child that Donald and Melania share, in the first lady's movie, though she delivers plenty of quotes about her pride in her son. Eighteen at the time of filming, Barron is only briefly mentioned or shown until the latter part of the film when inauguration weekend arrives.

 Melania describes him as a "confident man" in voiceover audio and at one point reminisces about him taking swim lessons at Mar-a-Lago with her father, Viktor Knavs, before later taking tennis lessons with her. She later chuckles on camera when she hears Jake Tapper comment on his height while watching live CNN coverage of Inauguration Day.

 The most telling moment about how Barron handled the turbulent events of 2024, while he was beginning his freshman year of college, comes as she discusses security for the inauguration alongside Donald, sharing that she has safety concerns after the assassination attempts toward Donald and noting that Barron would not feel comfortable getting out of a vehicle in public view. "I respect that," she says. "It's his decision."

 Barron's voice ‚Äî which became an unexpected point of curiosity on the internet after a childhood video of him with a Slovenian accent resurfaced ‚Äî is notably omitted from the film, with only one brief bit of audio captured on camera that comes out muffled.

 Melania does not interact with any of Donald's other children 

 Donald's four older children with Ivana Trump and Marla Maples appear in the documentary at various events along with their own families, though Melania is never shown interacting with any family members outside of her husband, her father and her son.

 The $40 million Amazon deal gets addressed 

 Amazon founder Jeff Bezos has worked to rebuild his relationship with Donald since his 2024 election victory and donated generously to his inaugural fund, raising questions about Amazon MGM Studios' decision to buy the rights to Melania for $40 million, which The Wall Street Journal claimed is the most the company has ever spent on a documentary.

 Seemingly anticipating criticism surrounding the $40 million price tag, the film briefly addressed the negotiations. In one scene, an aide for Melania gets a phone call where she is warned that a journalist at Puck is asking questions about how the deal came to be. The aide hangs up the phone and suggests in front of the camera that she's not interested in dealing with the reporter to try and defend it.

 Marc Beckman, Melania's senior adviser and agent, recently pushed back on the idea that the deal involved politics in a statement to PEOPLE, saying, "I negotiated the $40 million dollar deal on behalf of Melania Trump. My negotiation included several key players in Hollywood, such as Amazon MGM, Disney, Paramount, and Netflix."

 "Although record-breaking, our decision was equally motivated by Amazon MGM‚Äôs best-in-class team, its ability to launch in theaters worldwide, plus the docuseries, and its commitment to support a massive global marketing campaign," Beckman added.

 WSJ reported that Netflix and Apple declined to bid for the documentary, and that Paramount only bid $4 million. The outlet says the second-highest bid was from Disney, who offered $14 million.

 Jimmy Carter's funeral 

 The documentary spends a surprising amount of time on President Jimmy Carter's funeral on Jan. 9, 2025, though primarily because of the date's significance in Melania's personal life: Her mother, Amalija Knavs, died one year earlier on the same day.

 After the funeral service in Washington, during which she said she was caught up thinking about her mother, she returned to N.Y.C. and brought the documentary crew into St. Patrick's Cathedral to show her lighting a candle in Amalija's honor.

 Asking powerful political wives for guidance 

 While preparing her first lady initiatives in January 2025, Melania revealed in the documentary that she called on a couple of notable political wives for advice on how they've approached advocacy in their roles.

 She takes a video call with French first lady Brigitte Macron in Trump Tower, asking her how she has made progress tackling cyberbullying among children. As Macron talks about France's guidance that children should not have smartphones younger than 11 years old, Melania jots down on a blank pad of paper, "No phones until 11."

 She later invites Queen Rania of Jordan for a meeting to throw ideas around.

 Donald's reaction to realizing he has to ride with the Bidens 

 During a briefing on the Inauguration Day schedule with Donald and Melania, the couple were filmed learning that they would have some forced quality time with outgoing first couple Joe and Jill Biden. After the Bidens hosted them for a morning tea at the White House before the swearing-in ceremony, the Trumps were to join them in the same vehicle to ride over to the U.S. Capitol.

 "That's interesting," Donald reacts with skepticism. "That'll be an interesting drive."

 Though the documentary didn't capture the Trumps saying anything negative about the Bidens behind their backs on Inauguration Day, Donald was open about his dissatisfaction with Biden to the outgoing president's face during his public inauguration speech, portraying the Democrat as incompetent and saying, "From this moment on, America's decline is over."

 Kamala Harris' sigh before the transition 

 Moments before President Joe Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris were welcomed into the Capitol Rotunda to watch the transition of power to the incoming administration, Melania's documentary crew captured them backstage, appearing distraught by the moments to come.

 Two months earlier, Donald had defeated Harris in the presidential election, earning 312 Electoral College votes to her 226.

 Harris, in particular, looks agitated, and just before walking through the curtains to take her place on stage, lets out a heavy sigh.
news.summary: 'Melania' premiered globally in theaters on Friday, Jan. 30, sharing selective glimpses of the first lady's transition back to the White House
news.author: Kyler Alvord

news.title: Mason Gooding Thriller ‚ÄòThe Gates‚Äô Sets March Theatrical Release at Lionsgate Premiere | Exclusive
news.text:
Lionsgate Premiere, the studio‚Äôs specialty arm, will release ‚ÄúThe Gates,‚Äù a thriller starring Mason Gooding, Algee Smith, Keith Powers and James Van Der Beek, in select theaters on Mar. 13, TheWrap has exclusively learned.

The film marks the second feature from writer-director John Burr, following his 2017 supernatural thriller ‚ÄúMuse,‚Äù which played the horror and thriller festival circuit before landing on Tubi.

‚ÄúThe Gates‚Äù follows three college students ‚Äî Derek, Kevin and Tyon (Gooding, Smith and Powers) ‚Äî on a road trip gone wrong. The trio takes an ill-advised shortcut through a remote gated community, where they find themselves trapped after witnessing a murder. Over the course of the night, they are blamed, hunted and fractured by their own differing belief systems, while the perpetrator ‚Äî played by Van Der Beek ‚Äî emerges as the cunning patriarch who holds the entire community under his influence.

‚ÄúThis script is the most personal story I‚Äôve ever written,‚Äù Burr said in a statement to TheWrap. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs set in the community I lived in for the first half of my life, and its characters are an amalgam of myself and my closest friends growing up.‚Äù

‚ÄúGrowing up as a biracial person who identified strongly as half-black but who was afforded the occasional benefits that came with being able to pass as white, my perspectives often did not align with those of my white friends, while my experiences did not always align with those of my black friends,‚Äù Burr said in a statement. ‚ÄúTrusting authority figures was a privilege. Understanding that not all of my friends had that privilege was a journey. This film explores that journey through a propulsive genre lens.‚Äù

The film is produced by Nancy Leopardi (‚ÄúThe Cure‚Äù) of Indy Entertainment, Ross Kohn (‚ÄúMaggie Moore(s)‚Äù) of the newly launched Core 4 Films, and Gary Glushon (‚Äú24 Hours to Live‚Äù).

Executive producers include Michael Cassutt, John Harris, J. Todd Harris, Kamala Avila-Salmon, Arlie Day, Mike Page, Andy Dube, Courtney Henggeler, Eric Belgau, Damian Horan, David Gendron, Ali Jazayeri, Viviana Zarragoitia and Mason Gooding.

The film was made possible through the Oklahoma Film & Music incentive and the Cherokee Film incentive. Rebellium Films oversaw physical production, with financing provided by TPC.
news.summary:
The film marks the second feature from writer-director John Burr, following his 2017 supernatural thriller "Muse"

news.title: Springsteen performs new ICE protest song in Minneapolis
news.text:
Rock icon Bruce Springsteen took to the stage in Minneapolis on Friday to perform his new song written in tribute to two protesters shot dead by U.S. federal agents in the city.

The veteran performer penned and recorded ‚ÄúStreets of Minneapolis‚Äù in 24 hours, in what he said was a response to ‚Äústate terror‚Äù in the city, where U.S. President Donald Trump‚Äôs administration has sent thousands of heavily armed agents as part of an immigration clampdown.

Those agents killed two U.S. citizens, Alex Pretti and Renee Good, within a few weeks of each other, sparking widespread anger across the country, and accusations that the masked agents are out of control.

The Boss said after he had written the anthem, he sent it to former Rage Against The Machine frontman Tom Morello to see what he thought.

‚ÄúTom is an excitable man,‚Äù Springsteen told the audience to laughter as he took to the stage on Friday.

‚ÄúI said ‚ÄòTom, what do you think? It‚Äôs kind of soapboxey.‚Äô

‚ÄúAnd he says: ‚ÄòBruce, nuance is wonderful, but sometimes you have to kick them in the teeth.‚Äô‚Äù

READ MORE: Bruce Springsteen sings out against Trump in ‚ÄòStreets of Minneapolis‚Äô

Springsteen‚Äôs song calls the immigration agents ‚ÄúKing Trump‚Äôs private army‚Äù wearing ‚Äúoccupiers‚Äô boots‚Äù and with ‚Äúguns belted to their coats.‚Äù

‚ÄúThere were bloody footprints where mercy should have stood, and two dead left to die on snow-filled streets: Alex Pretti and Renee Good,‚Äù he sings in the opening verse.

‚ÄúThis is for the people of Minneapolis, the people of Minnesota and the people of our good country, the United States of America,‚Äù he told the audience.

The song‚Äôs title echoes the 1994 classic ‚ÄúStreets of Philadelphia,‚Äù Springsteen‚Äôs haunting ballad about people living with AIDS.

For decades, Springsteen has been revered by rock fans in the United States and beyond for his man-of-the-people guitar music and socially conscious, working-class anthems like ‚ÄúBorn in the USA,‚Äù ‚ÄúThe River,‚Äù and ‚ÄúRosalita.‚Äù

During the 2024 election campaign that led to Trump‚Äôs second presidency, Springsteen threw his support behind Democratic candidate Kamala Harris, and said Trump was running to be an ‚ÄúAmerican tyrant.‚Äù

At the time he said of Trump: ‚ÄúHe does not understand this country, its history or what it means to be deeply American.‚Äù

Trump has in recent days sought to tamp down the furor over the violence in Minneapolis and has shuffled the leadership of immigration officials overseeing the operation, putting a less confrontational figure in charge.

news.title: Trump‚Äôs arrest of journalists is the latest front in his effort to Orbanize the media
news.text:
Around this time nine years ago, Donald Trump, just a month into his first term, appeared at a conservative event where he delivered a highly provocative vow.

‚ÄúNo one loves the First Amendment more than me,‚Äù the Republican claimed before condemning the nation‚Äôs free press. Journalists, he said, ‚Äúhave their own agenda and it‚Äôs not your agenda. ... We're gonna do something about it.‚Äù

The quote came to mind anew on Friday morning. MS NOW reported:

Two journalists, including former CNN anchor Don Lemon, and two people active in Democratic circles in Minnesota have been arrested by federal agents investigating an anti-ICE protest that disrupted a church service.

Lemon was in Los Angeles to cover the Grammy Awards when he was taken into custody Thursday.

There was a recent protest during Sunday services at Cities Church in St. Paul, Minnesota, and the disruption was reportedly driven by demonstrators‚Äô belief that the church‚Äôs pastor works for Immigration and Customs Enforcement.

Soon after, federal agents arrested three of those involved with the protest, including civil rights attorney Nekima Levy Armstrong. Lemon, who was on hand for the developments, has now also been taken into custody, despite the longtime journalist‚Äôs insistence that he was at the church to cover the protest, not to participate in it.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm just here photographing, I‚Äôm not part of the group ... I‚Äôm a journalist,‚Äù Lemon is heard saying in one video of the event.

The Trump administration had tried to secure charges against Lemon in recent days, but to no avail. On Friday morning, however, Attorney General Pam Bondi boasted that he‚Äôd been arrested anyway ‚Äî a development the White House celebrated in an unusually provocative way.

Time will tell what becomes of the criminal case, and Lemon‚Äôs lawyer said he will ‚Äúfight these charges vigorously and thoroughly in court.‚Äù

But as the details of the case emerge, it‚Äôs worth pausing to appreciate the larger context.

Trump‚Äôs approach to the freedom of the press has never been especially healthy ‚Äî we are talking about a president who‚Äôs echoed Joseph Stalin in his attacks on journalists ‚Äî but his campaign against the media has gotten especially aggressive in recent months.

In September, for example, the Republican suggested that ‚Äúevening shows‚Äù are ‚Äúnot allowed‚Äù to criticize him and that networks that give him ‚Äúonly bad publicity‚Äù risk losing their broadcast licenses. At one point, the president went so far as to claim that broadcasters that air evening news programs are doing something ‚Äúillegal‚Äù if the White House disapproves of their coverage.

The list doesn‚Äôt stop there. Trump has sued news outlets that produce coverage he doesn‚Äôt like. He‚Äôs threatened media outlets over polling data he doesn‚Äôt like. He‚Äôs threatened to sic federal prosecutors on news organizations that publish reports he doesn‚Äôt like.

The FBI even searched the home of a Washington Post reporter and took her devices.

I‚Äôm not talking about tantrums the president has thrown over the last decade, I‚Äôm referring to specific incidents that have unfolded over the last six months.

That journalists have now been arrested is a dramatic escalation, but it‚Äôs not a development that came out of nowhere. On the contrary, Trump and his team have launched a systemic campaign against the nation‚Äôs free press that is without modern precedent in the United States ‚Äî and it‚Äôs clearly getting worse.

In the run-up to Election Day 2024, Trump was nearly as eager to attack the free press as he was to attack Kamala Harris. The Republican referred to journalists as ‚Äúthe enemy of the people,‚Äù media outlets as ‚Äúevil,‚Äù and news professionals as ‚Äúscum.‚Äù

But we‚Äôre well past the point of ugly taunts and name-calling. What we‚Äôre seeing is an authoritarian leader reading from the same playbook Viktor Orban used in Hungary, targeting journalists and journalism in the hopes of bringing it to heel.

In hindsight, ‚Äúno one loves the First Amendment more than me‚Äù might very well be one of the most offensive lies Trump has ever told.

news.title: The Melania ‚Äòdocumentary‚Äô might play in Orange County... but falls flat in NYC. Here‚Äôs why
news.text:
On a freezing January morning in New York City, I joined 19 fellow moviegoers in Auditorium 10 at AMC 34th Street 14 to watch one of the earliest public screenings in the U.S. of Melania, the $40 million Amazon ‚Äúdocumentary.‚Äù

It was obvious from the notepads resting on the tables of the 60-seat theater that most were members of the press, but at least two members of the public had also bought tickets. 

‚ÄúI came mostly out of curiosity,‚Äù 55-year-old New Yorker and astrologer Alan Lin told The Independent. 

Another civilian who arrived halfway through the 104-minute movie, and left again a short time later to get a soda, started vaping as the credits rolled. ‚ÄúI liked it,‚Äù he told The Independent after the movie ended. ‚ÄúBut I might have to go see it again because I missed most of it.‚Äù 

If more people went to see the movie twice, it could give ticket sales a boost. Unsurprisingly, sales are proving stronger in more conservative areas like Orange County, California, and Miami, Florida. According to a Wired analysis, only two screenings in the U.S. have completely sold out ‚Äî one at an AMC in Independence, Missouri, and one at an AMC in Vero Beach, Florida, an hour‚Äôs drive north of the Trumps‚Äô residence, Mar-a-Lago.

Trump played down the weak ticket sales at his wife‚Äôs premiere at the Kennedy Center. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a very tough business in theaters selling movie tickets after Covid,‚Äù he said Thursday night.

While Melania has been released with much fanfare, you wouldn‚Äôt know it from this New York theater, where it was competing with Academy Award-nominated Marty Supreme and Hamnet, alongside reruns of the Lord of the Rings trilogy. 

The 10:10 a.m. screening ‚Äî never likely to be the busiest ‚Äî was on the highest level of the four-storey complex. Promotional posters for Melania were nowhere to be found.

The first lady is said to be pocketing more than 70 percent of the $40 million Amazon paid to license the film, according to The Wall Street Journal. It was directed by Brett Ratner, the disgraced Hollywood director behind Rush Hour, who first met the Trumps in 2011. He hopes, it‚Äôs been reported, that this film will be his big comeback moment following a string of sexual misconduct allegations in 2017, which he denies and has not been charged over.

While much has been made in the film of the first lady‚Äôs inauguration day ‚ÄúHamburglar‚Äù hat; the golden eggs filled with caviar that guests were served at a banquet on the eve of the ceremony; and several mentions of how tall Barron is, the so-called documentary also serves as a vehicle to promote the MAGA-Trump agenda. 

Melania was paid as an executive producer and given direct control over everything in the film‚Äôs editorial content, culminating in a product that provides viewers with a narrow window into the ‚Äúreality‚Äù of what kind of first lady she planned to be the second time around.

Much of the film focuses on the first lady‚Äôs messages of ‚Äúunity‚Äù and ‚Äúhumanity,‚Äù themes that now jar with scenes that have played out in Minnesota, and other U.S. states, over the past year as a result of the president‚Äôs anti-immigration operation. 

‚ÄúThe weight of history intertwined with my own journey as an immigrant ... is a reminder of why I respect this nation so deeply,‚Äù Melania says in the film. ‚ÄúNo matter where we come from, we are bound by the same humanity.‚Äù 

There are glimmers of causes that the first lady admires. There is a brief video call with First Lady of France Brigitte Macron, where the women share their concerns about the harms of social media on children, and Melania touts her ‚ÄúFostering the Future‚Äù initiative. 

But the second half of the film focuses on behind-the-scenes-style footage - the buildup to and of inauguration day - where the viewer learns nothing new.

During one of the glitzy inaugural banquets, there are glimpses of Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos, Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg and the president‚Äôs former ‚Äúfirst buddy‚Äù Elon Musk ‚Äî a reminder of the role Big Tech has played in the making of the film and bankrolling other parts of the Trump administration‚Äôs agenda, such as his new ballroom, and donating to the inauguration itself.

There are a couple of not-so-subtle digs at Democrats. A shot of former Vice President Kamala Harris checking her watch during the inauguration was included, footage of the Trumps waving at the Bidens as they depart the White House aboard Marine One, and a portrait of former President Barack Obama in the White House that has since been moved to a hidden stairwell. 

The movie is packed with flashy shots of Mrs Trump jetting between her home in the gold-plated Trump Tower penthouse in New York City and Mar-a-Lago. 

The occasional interactions between the first lady and the president ‚Äî including one where she cannot get him off the phone quickly enough and cuts him short with a ‚ÄúCongrats‚Äù after he calls to brag about election results ‚Äî also shed no further light on their marriage.

At the end, Boney. M‚Äôs Sunny accompanies footage of Melania posing for her official portraits as first lady, with the lyrics ‚Äúthe dark days are gone, and the bright days are here‚Äù playing.

Whatever the first lady‚Äôs vision was for a ‚Äúunifying‚Äù a second term, it‚Äôs clear that the nation is more divided than ever.

Can anybody be entirely impartial when reviewing Melania?

Perhaps not. The Amazon MGM documentary about the first lady directed by scandal-plagued filmmaker Brett Ratner with a whopping $75 million price tag (or ‚Äúbribe,‚Äù as Jimmy Kimmel called it) provokes all sorts of feelings ‚Äî regardless of one‚Äôs political leanings ‚Äî before you even enter the theater.

But reviews are rolling in just the same, and below are samples of some of the (almost entirely scathing) critiques. Melania is billed as an inside look at Donald Trump‚Äòs partner as she prepared to return to the White House during the 20 days before the 2025 inauguration. The film is rolling out into more than 1,500 theaters across the U.S. this weekend, and its box office returns are being closely watched as a political barometer of sorts.

Related Stories

Selling 'Melania': Brett Ratner and the First Lady Discuss the Making of Their Controversial $75 Million Amazon Doc

'Melania' Review: Brett Ratner's Melania Trump Documentary Is an Unabashed, Fly-on-the-Gilded-Wall Fawn Job

The reviews below are coming out just as the film is hitting the screens. Mainstream press were reportedly blocked from attending the film‚Äôs premiere at the Kennedy Center on Thursday. While screenshots of theaters with unsold seats have been circulating on social media, tracking service NRG has predicted a launch in the $5 million range ‚Äî which would be enormously successful for a documentary. Exhibitors are less certain, however.

Here are some of the early critiques:

The Hollywood Reporter: ‚ÄúThis is a film that fawns so lavishly over its subject that you feel downright unpatriotic not gushing over it ‚Ä¶ The expensive propaganda doc is glossily shot and lushly scored, although for some reason Ratner keeps inserting segments shot on what looks like Super 8 film, as if to infuse the Trumps with some of that Kennedy-era aura. Before the film ends with onscreen graphics listing Melania‚Äôs achievements as first lady in such laudatory fashion that North Korea would blush, she‚Äôs shown posing for her official portrait. Doing her best to look both sexy and authoritative, she seems most in her element.‚Äù

The Atlantic called the film ‚Äúa disgrace,‚Äù saying, ‚ÄúRatner seems desperate to find action, but there is none. The pace is stultifying ‚Ä¶ Mostly, Ratner captures his subject walking from liminal place to liminal place in five-inch heels, the camera trailing her like a lap dog ‚Ä¶ Melania the movie isn‚Äôt a documentary; it‚Äôs a protection racket. It‚Äôs a reminder that the richest people in the world are investing in entertainment brands not because they care about art but because the public does, and because all of these vanity projects and capitulations are a way to consolidate their own power and fortune.‚Äù

The Guardian: ‚ÄúRatner‚Äôs film plays like a gilded trash remake of Jonathan Glazer‚Äôs The Zone of Interest in which a button-eyed Cinderella points at gold baubles and designer dresses, cunningly distracting us while her husband and his cronies prepare to dismantle the Constitution and asset-strip the federal government ‚Ä¶ the fun‚Äôs not infectious and the guests are a nightmare, and two hours of Melania feels like pure, endless hell.‚Äù

The Daily Beast: ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to blow anyone‚Äôs minds here or throw you off your balance when I inform you the Melania documentary is terrible. Were it not for scattered laughter-inducing scenes ‚Äî most of which, I would gather, were not intentionally humorous ‚Äî I would rule it an abomination.‚Äù

Variety: ‚ÄúIt feels like it‚Äôs been stitched together out of the most innocuous outtakes from a reality show. There‚Äôs no drama to it. It should have been called Day of the Living Tradwife ‚Ä¶ Its very existence is a pure expression of that control. By the time Melania arrives at the Inaugural festivities, the film has given itself over to a series of rituals (the candlelight dinner, the Inaugural itself, the luncheon, the Starlight Ball), which feels weirdly fitting since the filmmaking itself is so ritualized. It never lets the air of experience in.‚Äù

The London Evening Standard gave the film its only positive review so far (thus ensuring Melania will not have a 0 percent critics score on Rotten Tomatoes): ‚ÄúIf you take this film for what it is, Melania‚Äôs own, curated take on herself, then there‚Äôs one thing she wants to get across, it‚Äôs that there‚Äôs human warmth there under the cheekbones and the slanting feline eyes. May I say right now she looks extraordinary for 55? ‚Ä¶ Is the film worth $40 million? I can‚Äôt see it myself, except for the shot of Kamala Harris at the inauguration, which is worth the entrance ticket ‚Ä¶ She‚Äôs a phenomenon. What, exactly, is her relationship with Trump, who was effusive about, ‚Äòmy beautiful wife‚Äô? We don‚Äôt know. The enigma remains.‚Äù

The Independent: ‚ÄúTo call Melania vapid would do a disservice to the plumes of florid vape smoke that linger around British teenagers. She calls herself a ‚Äòmother, wife, daughter, friend,‚Äô yet is only depicted preening and scowling ‚Ä¶ Trump himself is an instantly more charismatic presence on screen. His scenes offer a relief from Melania‚Äôs mask of pure nothingness ‚Ä¶ It will exist as a striking artifact ‚Äî like The Birth of a Nation or Triumph of the Will ‚Äî of a time when Americans willingly subordinated themselves to a political and economic oligopoly.‚Äù

news.title: 'John Fetterman Has Completely Sold Out': Philly DA Slams Trump's 'Favorite Senator'
news.text:
Philadelphia District Attorney Larry Krasner on Thursday said Sen. John Fetterman (D-Pa.) has ‚Äúcompletely sold out,‚Äù slamming the fellow Democrat on CNN for condemning rhetoric that likens U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement to Nazis, saying it can ‚Äúincite violence.‚Äù

‚ÄúJohn Fetterman is ... the favorite Democratic senator of Donald Trump,‚Äù Krasner said during an appearance on ‚ÄúThe Source with Kaitlin Collins.‚Äù ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs said that repeatedly. And that‚Äôs because John Fetterman has completely sold out the principles on which he ran for office.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut what he‚Äôs been doing, for quite some time, for whatever reason ‚Äî and we all know there may be a few reasons ‚Äî is completely unacceptable for anyone who actually believes in democracy and who actually believes in the rule of law,‚Äù continued Krasner, who said he voted for Fetterman.

Conservative news outlets scrutinized Krasner earlier this week after he stated that ICE agents are ‚Äúa small bunch of wannabe Nazis,‚Äù adding ‚Äúwe outnumber them‚Äù and warning they could be ‚Äúhunted down‚Äù like the Nazis were after World War II. This led to a rebuke from Fetterman.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs gross, and I absolutely condemn that, absolutely,‚Äù Fetterman said on Wednesday on Fox News. ‚ÄúDo not compare anyone to Nazis. Don‚Äôt use that kind of rhetoric. That can incite violence and ... I strongly reject that and condemn that kind of language in the strongest terms. You know, members of ICE are not Nazis.‚Äù

Fetterman ‚Äî who had regularly criticized Trump over his false claims about the 2020 election ‚Äî later became the only Democratic senator to support Trump‚Äôs 2024 nomination for Attorney General Pam Bondi and criticized former Vice President Kamala Harris for calling Trump a ‚Äúfascist.‚Äù Trump last year called Fetterman ‚Äúthe most sensible‚Äù Democrat.

Krasner vowed earlier this week to prosecute federal officers who break state laws following Saturday‚Äôs fatal shooting of Alex Pretti, joining a coalition of prosecutors dubbed ‚ÄúFight Against Federal Overreach,‚Äù or F.A.F.O. ‚Äî a cheeky reference to the acronym for ‚Äúfuck around and find out,‚Äù which has become a favorite phrase of Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth and other members of the Trump administration.

Political tensions surrounding the Trump administration‚Äôs anti-immigration raids became increasingly fraught after an ICE officer killed Minneapolis resident Renee Good earlier this month, and eyewitness videos caught Border Protection officers fatally shooting Pretti.

When asked on CNN Thursday if he couldn‚Äôt have made his point about ICE without comparing them to Nazis, Krasner replied, ‚ÄúWhy would I do that? The reality is, they‚Äôre taking almost everything they do out of the Nazi playbook.‚Äù

Krasner noted that he hadn‚Äôt said ‚Äúall‚Äù ICE agents were like Nazis; however, he added that there are ‚Äúa lot of great federal officers,‚Äù but those who commit alleged crimes like homicide should be treated ‚Äúlike everyone else‚Äù by the U.S. criminal justice system.

‚ÄúThe point I was making is actually very straightforward,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWhen you kill people, we can hunt you down and bring you to justice, in 10 years, or 20 or 30 years, just like what happened with the Golden State Killer, who was a serial killer in California.‚Äù

Krasner continued, ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs how it worked. It worked that way with the Nazis, but it also works that way with all kinds of other criminals who commit terrible crimes.‚Äù

news.title: Joe Rogan skips Golden Globes after refusing to pay entry fee for podcast award nomination
news.text: Joe Rogan took aim at the Golden Globes after revealing he declined to pay a fee to be nominated for the awards show‚Äôs inaugural podcast category. Speaking on his podcast, Rogan said organizers had asked him to formally submit his show for consideration, but that he had refused to pay the $500 application fee required to be nominated. "A lot of people say, ‚ÄòWhy wasn‚Äôt Joe Rogan nominated for the Golden Globes? Why did Amy Poehler win?‚Äô I didn‚Äôt submit," Rogan said. ‚ÄòTHAT SOUNDS SO REPUBLICAN‚Äô: JOE ROGAN STUNNED BY OBAMA‚ÄôS OLD DEPORTATION RHETORIC "They asked me to submit to be nominated for the Golden Globes and you had to pay $500. And the $500 is like for paperwork or whatever. I said, ‚ÄòNo,‚Äô" he added. "The Joe Rogan Experience" has remained one of the most listened-to podcasts in the world and was eligible for the category. The show has ranked No. 1 on Spotify for several years and has also topped Apple Podcasts and YouTube rankings. Rogan argued that audience reach matters more than industry awards, saying, "You can‚Äôt tell me I didn‚Äôt win. I‚Äôve been No. 1 for six years in a row." GOLDEN GLOBE WINNER RECOUNTS HEATED EXCHANGE WITH FIRST-CLASS AIRLINE PASSENGER: 'MY BOSTON CAME OUT' "All of a sudden, you‚Äôre gonna have a contest in front of all these people wearing tuxedos, and you‚Äôre gonna say now I‚Äôm not No. 1?" Comedian Amy Poehler‚Äôs podcast "Good Hang" won the award. The decision drew criticism on social media, with users noting the podcast is less than a year old while other nominees have been on the air longer. Rogan defended her win, saying, "I‚Äôm sure it‚Äôs good. It won. I‚Äôm sure someone must love it. If it sucked, they would give it to someone else, right?" MAHER SHREDS GOLDEN GLOBES FOR NOT NOMINATING JOE ROGAN FOR BEST PODCAST, SAYS THEY LIVE IN A 'F------ BUBBLE' Other nominees in the category were "The Mel Robbins Podcast," "SmartLess," "Up First" and "Armchair Expert with Dax Shepard." news.title: Melania Trump reveals nothing in this glitzy and gross bit of propaganda
news.text:
Forty million dollars is an awful lot of money to spend on filming the back of a woman‚Äôs balayage as she gets in and out of Range Rovers for three weeks.

Not for Jeff Bezos. That, for whatever honest artistic or nefarious political reasons, is what Amazon has paid for the rights to distribute Melania, the new documentary ‚Äì the most expensive ever made ‚Äì charting the 20 days before Melania Trump‚Äôs return to the White House in 2025, and how the enigmatic First Lady seeks to ‚Äúreinvent‚Äù, ‚Äúelevate‚Äù and ‚Äúbreak old norms‚Äù of the job of being Donald Trump‚Äôs wife.

Melania has been controversial from the moment it was announced. There‚Äôs the money ‚Äì with an additional $35m budget for marketing ‚Äì and the obvious fact that the project, with 55-year-old Melania herself serving as executive producer, is shameless propaganda.

There‚Äôs the unconscionable choice of director Brett Ratner, of Rush Hour fame, who has been excommunicated from Hollywood since six women accused him of sexual assault allegations in 2017 (no charges were brought). And there are the rumours of unrest on the production itself: Amazon mandated that no staff could opt out of the project for political reasons, two-thirds have reportedly removed their names from the credits, and many have made complaints about Ratner‚Äôs on-set behaviour.

It has been secretive ‚Äì no advance press screenings have been held. The box office sales have reportedly been ‚Äúsoft‚Äù in the UK, despite Donald Trump‚Äôs insistence otherwise on Truth Social. At the showing I went to, four people in the seven-strong audience were journalists. 

And the timing could not be worse. The United States is a country in turmoil, with Trump threatening to take over Greenland and two people fatally shot by federal forces in Minnesota amid mass protests of an immigration crackdown. This glitzy documentary is simultaneously in horrible bad taste, and a news event promising to shed light on one of the most powerful women in the world.

For a few moments, as Melania‚Äôs opening scene swept us over the beach at Mar-a-Lago and zoomed in on a snakeskin Louboutin stiletto with Mick Jagger wailing along to ‚ÄúGimme Shelter‚Äù, I was afraid that Ratner might have delivered a work of glamorous, self-aware high camp that I might have to report I enjoyed.

This was swiftly kiboshed, however, as Melania‚Äôs voiceover ‚Äì as monotone as her wardrobe ‚Äì kicked in. She introduces herself ‚Äúnavigating the complexities of life‚Äù and takes us into a suite at Trump Tower overlooking Central Park, as she and a group of sycophantic seamstresses compare different shades of navy blue.

What follows are a series of loose and mostly unconnected diary events from January 2024. Melania is fitted for a ballgown; Melania assesses the champagne coupes for a candlelit dinner and the ‚Äúbeautiful shades of greige‚Äù for the White House interiors; Melania hires her new staff; Melania has a Zoom call with Brigitte Macron about ‚Äúchildren‚Äù ‚Äì all while explaining how detail-oriented and fashion conscious and focused on her initiatives she is.

If there was any reflection whatsoever into the messages she intends to project with her fashion, how she feels about hosting thousands of people at official events, how and why she has redecorated the White House, what she looks for in the team around her and what she expects them to do, or the reasons behind her chosen philanthropic causes, this might threaten to be a film of substance. Alas it ‚Äì beautifully shot, and with a killer soundtrack featuring Spandau Ballet, Tears for Fears, and Michael Jackson, Melania‚Äôs favourite ‚Äì is all style. (The only takeaway about her style is that she likes the colours black and white.)

We travel on Trump Force One as the Slovenian-born former model jets between New York, Washington and Mar-a-Lago, which she calls her ‚Äúrefuge from the outside world‚Äù. Watching this, in which opulence is everywhere, it is very difficult to imagine she was ever in it.

The real world is ignored, with some vulgarity, but when reality does encroach, it is with detachment: she watches the California wildfires on TV with sympathy from a luxuriant sofa (it may as well be an ivory tower), attends the funeral of Jimmy Carter and is reminded of her own mother‚Äôs death a year before, and meets a freed Israeli hostage, Aviva Siegel, fighting for her husband Keith to be released from Gaza.

That scene is moving and as emotional as Melania gets ‚Äì Trump helped secure her husband‚Äôs rescue days after he was sworn in ‚Äì and Melania displays warmth and compassion in the face of raw distress. But you would have to be a monster not to. Nowhere else do we see her bond, there is no suggestion of any friendships, we don‚Äôt see anything candid or vulnerable or even, really, human.

Which is not to say she comes across as badly as she quite obviously must be, given her marriage ‚Äì she seems nice, composed, and articulate ‚Äì she is just not interested in letting anyone in. Even in the long sequence at St Patrick‚Äôs Cathedral, as she pays tribute to her late mother and discusses her ongoing grief, she does not share details about what she was like or display emotion of any kind.

This is true of the whole film, which ‚Äì instead of a personal portrait or a reflection on her experiences in the White House and how they changed her, how she feels about a second term, her nerves about the inauguration and returning to a life of duty ‚Äì is really a string of platitudes. About America, about her husband, about fallen soldiers, about the momentousness of returning to the White House, about the immigrant experience.

In Washington she ‚Äúfelt the weight of history intertwined with my own journey as an immigrant‚Äù (given the anger and despair of American immigrants at the moment, this feels especially crass). At Arlington National Cemetery she is humbled by the servicemen and women defending her rights and reminded that we are all ‚Äúbound by humanity‚Äù. Inauguration Day was ‚Äúso rich with meaning‚Äù.

Those of us who watched news coverage of the day are forced to relive much of that rich meaning again here, with a bonus shot of Kamala Harris checking her watch. Each moment of that 22-hour media opp, Melania insists, was ‚Äúfilled with historic purpose‚Äù. Conspiracy theorists who accuse her of being a body double or dead will have to concede that from the way this woman speaks, it is obvious she has spent several decades around the bluster of Donald Trump. Whom, if it wasn‚Äôt obvious enough, we learn little about.

We see one conversation in which he drones on and she tries to get him off the phone, another in which she wryly offers edits for his inaugural speech (which he reluctantly takes). I did enjoy hearing them catch up about 19-year-old Barron, the president revealing ‚ÄúI love him, he‚Äôs cute, we have cute conversations‚Äù to his wife, as if discussing a neighbour‚Äôs toddler rather than their own nearly adult son.

Melania is worse than a bad film ‚Äì it‚Äôs a boring one. A documentary must have failed its subject if you come away less curious about them than before, and I found myself much more interested in the people around the First Lady, those desperate for proximity to her gilded cage, than the woman herself. The White House staff, the drivers, the stylists, the young women interviewing for jobs in the East Wing.

A documentary also must have failed its subject if you wind up wanting to hear more from her husband. Which is the worst part of all: in the hope of comedy, in the hope of drama, in the hope of a twist, I watched Melania and found myself wishing there had been more of Donald Trump.

Melania is in cinemas now

news.title: What‚Äôs a ‚ÄòYinzer‚Äô? Our reporters‚Äô roundtable with Gov. Josh Shapiro.
news.text:
Reporters packed the room Thursday for a Monitor Breakfast event with Pennsylvania Gov. Josh Shapiro. And there were plenty of national issues to discuss ‚Äì immigration raids, political violence, rising antisemitism.

But when a reporter introduced herself as having ‚ÄúPittsburgh roots,‚Äù Governor Shapiro couldn‚Äôt resist going local.

‚ÄúGreat, another Yinzer!‚Äù he said, using Pittsburgh slang for a city resident. ‚ÄúAre you still a Steelers fan?‚Äù

Yes, she assured him. ‚ÄúStillers,‚Äù Mr. Shapiro threw in, again shifting to Pittsburghese. (He‚Äôs from Philadelphia, but is apparently bilingual.)

The governor is on a book tour, promoting his memoir, ‚ÄúWhere We Keep the Light.‚Äù The book paints a self-portrait of a man who‚Äôs all about his family, his Jewish faith, and ‚Äúgetting stuff done.‚Äù

But for the media, the interest is all about 2028 and the widely held assumption that Mr. Shapiro, a Democrat, will run for president. At a time of deep national division, he prides himself on his ability to work across the aisle.

Still, ask Mr. Shapiro straight up if he‚Äôs running, as the reporter from Pittsburgh did, and he demurs. Because he has to. He‚Äôs up for reelection this November, and while he‚Äôs strongly favored to win, the midterm elections are on a razor‚Äôs edge ‚Äì both for control of the U.S. Congress and his state legislature. Pennsylvania is the nation‚Äôs biggest swing state, and he enjoys high approval ratings.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think we should be thinking about anything other than curtailing the chaos, the cruelty, and the corruption of this administration,‚Äù Mr. Shapiro says, as quoted in the Monitor‚Äôs coverage.

But the governor‚Äôs book did make waves earlier this month, pre-release, when a reporter got an advance copy and highlighted the controversy over his vetting by Kamala Harris‚Äôs team for the vice-presidency in 2024. Mr. Shapiro expressed upset over this question: ‚ÄúHave you ever been an agent for the Israeli government?‚Äù

In the book, Mr. Shapiro cries antisemitism. The issue of vetting came up last week in our Monitor Breakfast event with another prominent Jewish Democrat, former Chicago Mayor Rahm Emanuel. Mr. Emanuel expressed sympathy with both sides, saying the question was ‚Äúnot artful, but you have to ask.‚Äù Yet another top Jewish Democrat, Illinois Gov. JB Pritzker, also defended the process as ‚Äútough‚Äù but necessary.

Notably, all three men are widely viewed as eyeing the presidency. And thus the issue of rising antisemitism could be a dominant theme in 2028. Indeed, the night before our roundtable with Mr. Shapiro, a motorist rammed his car multiple times into a major Jewish institution, the Chabad-Lubavitch world headquarters, in Brooklyn, New York. The incident is being investigated as a hate crime.

In fact, I told Mr. Shapiro after our event had ended, I have personally experienced antisemitism. I have received nasty emails from people who assume I‚Äôm Jewish, I said. ‚ÄúLovely, just forward them to me,‚Äù Mr. Shapiro responded.

On a lighter note, in our post-roundtable chit-chat, we got back to the subject of football. The night before, while doing a book event in Boston, Mr. Shapiro mentioned visiting with Robert Kraft, the owner of the New England Patriots who is also working to fight antisemitism. My ears perked up.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm so sorry,‚Äù I said, ‚Äúbut I‚Äôm from Boston. Go Pats!‚Äù

After several bad years, the Patriots are back in the Super Bowl. Mr. Shapiro was gracious, given that his hometown Philadelphia Eagles, who won the Super Bowl last year, won‚Äôt repeat.

‚ÄúI lived through those lean years with the birds, with the Eagles,‚Äù the governor said, ‚Äúand so it‚Äôs kind of neat to see them [the Patriots] as good as they are.‚Äù
news.summary: Josh Shapiro‚Äôs book tour may be laying the groundwork for a presidential run. At an event with reporters, the governor also showed his Pennsylvania roots.
news.author: Linda Feldmann

news.title: What the ‚ÄòMelania‚Äô movie reveals (and what it leaves out)
news.text:
The biggest revelation of the Melania Trump movie is that there are none.

Over the course of 104 unhurried minutes, ‚ÄúMelania‚Äù (in theaters now) follows the first lady as she gets dress fittings, picks out carpet swatches and interviews potential candidates for her staff, all in preparation for her family‚Äôs move back to the White House in January 2025.

There are some personal observations, as she remarks on the ‚Äúquiet strength‚Äù of her late mother, Amalija Knavs, and praises the ‚Äúintelligent mind‚Äù of the couple's 19-year-old son, Barron. But for a documentary about the lead-up to President Donald Trump‚Äôs second inauguration, the commander in chief stays very much in the periphery.

Here are the most noteworthy moments of the film, which is executive produced by the first lady and directed by disgraced Hollywood filmmaker Brett Ratner:

President Trump jokes that Melania is ‚Äòvery difficult‚Äô but an ‚Äòincredible‚Äô first lady

Trump only appears a handful of times throughout ‚ÄúMelania.‚Äù Early in the movie, he can be heard in voiceover as she chats with him on the phone. ‚ÄúHi, honey,‚Äù he says, to which she responds, ‚ÄúHi, Mr. President.‚Äù He calls the election results ‚Äúa big win,‚Äù adding that he won the popular vote in a landslide and had not anticipated such high numbers.

Later, he greets Melania as she gets off the plane in Washington, kissing her on the cheek as he says she looks ‚Äúvery beautiful‚Äù like ‚Äúa movie star.‚Äù

The few occasions that Trump does speak to the film cameras, it‚Äôs to compliment his wife. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs the most incredible first lady ‚Ä¶ She‚Äôs very difficult, but there‚Äôs nobody like her,‚Äù Trump says with a laugh, adding that she‚Äôs ‚Äúnot difficult‚Äù before bidding her goodnight.

Donald Trump wonders why his inauguration has to ‚Äòcompete‚Äô with football

During a visit to their Florida home of Mar-a-Lago, Trump and Melania meet with staffers to nail down Inauguration Day plans. His team tells him that he‚Äôll be riding with President Joe Biden to the U.S. Capitol on the day. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôll be an interesting drive,‚Äù Trump says with a smirk.

The couple proceeds to ask questions about their safety, as well as why the College Football Playoff national championship game between Ohio State and Notre Dame is being broadcast on Inauguration Day.

‚ÄúWe have to compete with the championship? How did that happen?‚Äù Trump queries, adding ‚ÄúI think they did that on purpose.‚Äù

In that same exchange, he looks at a photo from his 2017 inauguration, where Melania wore a sky-blue Ralph Lauren dress with matching gloves. Trump then turns to Melania and asks, ‚ÄúYou have a good dress? You have a nice dress? This one blew everyone away.‚Äù He asks if her 2025 inauguration outfit can compete, to which she laughs. 

Barron Trump is mostly MIA during the 'Melania' movie

Barron has largely stayed out of the spotlight during both of his father‚Äôs presidential terms, and he is now in his second year at New York University.

On the rare occasions that he does appear in the documentary, he is filmed from the back or in side profile, save for a shot of him waving to the crowd during an inauguration celebration at Capital One Arena in Washington, which is soundtracked by ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a Man‚Äôs, Man‚Äôs, Man‚Äôs World‚Äù by James Brown & the Famous Flames.

‚ÄúBarron is a very confident young man,‚Äù Melania says in voiceover, adding that he got ‚Äúquite the reception‚Äù at the event. At other points in the film, she praises her son for having a good head on his shoulders, explaining that she‚Äôs excited to see him forge his own path and start a family one day.

Melania Trump does the ‚ÄòYMCA,‚Äô sings along to Michael Jackson

As noted, ‚ÄúMelania‚Äù is short on genuine insight into the first lady and her duties. The film briefly features both virtual and in-person meetings with Queen Rania of Jordan, France‚Äôs first lady Brigitte Macron, and freed Israeli hostage Aviva Siegel, as Melania gets involved with various humanitarian causes.

She speaks broadly in platitudes about serving the American people and leading with love: ‚ÄúI‚Äôll move forward with purpose,‚Äù Melania says at the end of the film. ‚ÄúAnd, of course, a sense of style.‚Äù

The few times that we really get to see the more human side of Melania are while she dances and half-sings along to both Michael Jackson‚Äôs ‚ÄúBillie Jean‚Äù and Village People‚Äôs ‚ÄúYMCA.‚Äù at various points. She laughs at a CNN inauguration broadcast, as the anchors marvel at how tall Barron is. (He is 6-foot-9, to be fair.)

And although she doesn‚Äôt cry, per se, Melania appears visibly emotional during one scene as she watches news coverage of last year‚Äôs Los Angeles wildfires. 

Donald Trump chats with President Joe Biden, pats him on the shoulder

A handful of famous faces appear throughout the documentary, including tech giants Elon Musk and Mark Zuckerberg at different inaugural events, as well as Trump‚Äôs presidential opponent, Vice President Kamala Harris, during the ceremony itself. None of them are heard speaking in the film.

Biden and his wife, first lady Jill Biden, also appear a few times, as they pose for a picture with the Trumps on Inauguration Day. Before boarding Air Force One, Trump looks back at Biden and gives him a tap on the shoulder, and the two men can be seen chatting by the helicopter outside the U.S. Capitol.
